body.p: There is a rich history of using history to examine a variety of organizational phenomenon. Leblebici and his colleagues used the history of the radio industry to examine institutional change (Leblebici, Salancik, Copay, & King, 1991). In my own work, I have used the history of U.S. collegiate athletics to examine how institutions are created and compete with other institutions (Washington & Ventresca, 2008). In Journal of Management Inquiry fashion, there have been historical projects published examining the leadership styles of Mary Parker Follett and Joseph Smith (Mendenhall & Marsh, 2010), and the institutional entrepreneurship of Rachel Carson (Kisfalvi & Maguire, 2011). In this article, Lohrke, Ahlstrom, and Bruton contribute to our understanding of organizational turnaround processes by examining the case of Abraham Lincoln and the U.S. Civil War. After providing wonderful rich history of how President Lincoln was able to lead the north to victory in the Civil War, the authors then develop propositions based on their study that challenge and extend the current understanding of organizational turnaround processes.
